title: China donates FCFA 10 million worth of Agricultural tools and Office Equipment to Ex-Servicemen and War Victims in Cameroon
description: On April 25th, 2017, Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon handed over agricultural tools and office equipment to Ex-Servicemen and War Victims in Cameroon. This donation was given to Cameroon's Secretary of State in the Ministry of Defense in charge of Ex-Servicemen and War Victims, Koumpa Issa, from the Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon, Wei Wenhua. The materials comprising of cutlasses, hoes, sprayers, watering cans, rain boats, wheel barrows, trucks, dig axe, artisanal oil milling machine, six computers and two printers are worth FCFA 10 million. This project is completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates FCFA 10 million worth of Agricultural tools and Office Equipment to Ex-Servicemen and War Victims in Cameroon

# Description
On April 25th, 2017, Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon handed over agricultural tools and office equipment to Ex-Servicemen and War Victims in Cameroon. This donation was given to Cameroon's Secretary of State in the Ministry of Defense in charge of Ex-Servicemen and War Victims, Koumpa Issa, from the Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon, Wei Wenhua. The materials comprising of cutlasses, hoes, sprayers, watering cans, rain boats, wheel barrows, trucks, dig axe, artisanal oil milling machine, six computers and two printers are worth FCFA 10 million. This project is completed.
justification: Project involves donation of agricultural tools and office equipment for social welfare purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Agricultural tools and office equipment donated to Ex-Servicemen and War Victims, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Embassy donates foodstuffs worth 107,000 CNY to Chantal Biya Foundation
description: On November 21, 2017, Wei Wenhua, Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon, donated 107,000 CNY (about 9 million FCFA) worth of foodstuff and other basic items to assist vulnerable people in the North West and South West Regions. This gift was given to Habissou Bidoung, Secretary General of the Chantal Biya Foundation, FCB. This was donated to the Chantal BIYA Foundation (FCB), a non-profit created by Cameroon's first lady, Chantal Biya, in an effort to provide assistance to vulnerable people across Cameroon. The status of this project is completed.
combined_text:
# Sector

This gift was given to Habissou Bidoung, Secretary General of the Chantal Biya Foundation, FCB. This was donated to the Chantal BIYA Foundation (FCB), a non-profit created by Cameroon's first lady, Chantal Biya, in an effort to provide assistance to vulnerable people across Cameroon. The status of this project is completed.
justification: Project involves donation of foodstuffs and basic items for social welfare purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of foodstuffs and basic items to assist vulnerable people, implemented through a non-profit foundation

title: China donates FCFA 8 million to Bakossi National Park in Cameroon
description: On December 18th, 2017, China donated equipment to the Bakossi National Park in the South West Region of Cameroon through the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) for the support of ecodevelopment and nature protection. The symbolic equipment worth FCFA 8 million were distributed to the Bakossi National Park service, Tombel Conservation and Development Cooperative and Bakossi Non-Timber Forest Product Cooperative. It consists of two motorcycles, a hand pulled truck, sleeping bags, walkie talkies, a tarpaulin, solar wax extractors, veils with caps, smokers, refractometers, amongst others.
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

# Title
China donates FCFA 8 million to Bakossi National Park in Cameroon

# Description
On December 18th, 2017, China donated equipment to the Bakossi National Park in the South West Region of Cameroon through the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) for the support of ecodevelopment and nature protection. The symbolic equipment worth FCFA 8 million were distributed to the Bakossi National Park service, Tombel Conservation and Development Cooperative and Bakossi Non-Timber Forest Product Cooperative. It consists of two motorcycles, a hand pulled truck, sleeping bags, walkie talkies, a tarpaulin, solar wax extractors, veils with caps, smokers, refractometers, amongst others.
justification: Project focuses on environmental protection and community development without direct energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of equipment for national park service and local cooperatives, focus on nature protection and ecodevelopment

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 216 million government concessional loan for Trade Facilitation and Electronic Certificate Verification E-Government Project (Linked to Project ID#57077)
description: On September 22, 2017, Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon Wei Wenhua and Cameroonian Minister of Economy, Planning and Territorial Rehabilitation Motaze signed three cooperation agreements on behalf of their respective governments (see Project ID#57077). One of these was a framework agreement for a China Eximbank government concessional loan (GCL) worth RMB 216 million for the Trade Facilitation and Electronic Certificate Verification E-Government Project. A GCL agreement was subsequently signed by the two parties. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a $33 million commercial contract with Anhui YISHANG Digital Science Co. Ltd. (易商数码 or 安徽易商数码科技有限公司).   This project entered implementation, but its precise implementation start and end dates are unknown.  There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Trade Facilitation and Electronic Certificate Verification E-Government Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In January 2019, Cameroon unilaterally withheld debt service payments to China Eximbank. The lender responded by withholding new loan disbursements. Then, in July 2019, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameroon signed a debt rescheduling agreement (as captured via Project ID#88213). Under the terms of the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to reschedule 18 loans previously contracted by the Government of Cameroon — with scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 — by allowing the borrower to defer scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 to later dates but without any maturity extensions. The total amount of restructured debt was equivalent CFA 148 billion ($253 million) — or 70% of the loan principal that was scheduled for repayment between July 2019 and March 2022. Under the terms of the agreement, the Government of Cameroon agreed to repay 30% of the loan principal according to the original July 2019-March 2022 schedule (i.e. without any payment deferrals). The lender and the borrower also agreed to cancel the committed but undisbursed loan balances worth approximately CFA 10 billion (for certain loans with disbursement deadlines that had already passed). Then, in January 2020, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) classified the Government Cameroon as facing a high risk of debt distress. Eighteen months later, during an address before Cameroon’s National Assembly on June 28, 2021, the Minister of Water and Energy (MINEE) Gaston Eloundou Esommba provided an update on the ICBC-financed Bini à Warak Hydroelectric Power Plant Project. He noted that the project had been 'on hold' since November 2019 because ICBC suspended the loan agreement, even though the Government of Cameroon had already mobilized XAF 22 billion of counterpart funding. He also explained that 'the reason for this suspension is that Cameroon did not settle some of its debts towards China on time, so, it is in a cross-default situation.’
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 喀麦隆贸易便利化与电子证书验证电子政务项目 or 喀麦隆贸易便利化及电子证书验证电子政务合作项目. The French project title is Projet de facilitation du commerce international or Projet E-governement de facilitation du commerce et du système de vérification de l’E-Certification.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 216 million government concessional loan for Trade Facilitation and Electronic Certificate Verification E-Government Project (Linked to Project ID#57077)

# Description
On September 22, 2017, Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon Wei Wenhua and Cameroonian Minister of Economy, Planning and Territorial Rehabilitation Motaze signed three cooperation agreements on behalf of their respective governments (see Project ID#57077). One of these was a framework agreement for a China Eximbank government concessional loan (GCL) worth RMB 216 million for the Trade Facilitation and Electronic Certificate Verification E-Government Project. A GCL agreement was subsequently signed by the two parties. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a $33 million commercial contract with Anhui YISHANG Digital Science Co. Ltd. (易商数码 or 安徽易商数码科技有限公司).   This project entered implementation, but its precise implementation start and end dates are unknown.  There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Trade Facilitation and Electronic Certificate Verification E-Government Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In January 2019, Cameroon unilaterally withheld debt service payments to China Eximbank. The lender responded by withholding new loan disbursements. Then, in July 2019, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameroon signed a debt rescheduling agreement (as captured via Project ID#88213). Under the terms of the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to reschedule 18 loans previously contracted by the Government of Cameroon — with scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 — by allowing the borrower to defer scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 to later dates but without any maturity extensions. The total amount of restructured debt was equivalent CFA 148 billion ($253 million) — or 70% of the loan principal that was scheduled for repayment between July 2019 and March 2022. Under the terms of the agreement, the Government of Cameroon agreed to repay 30% of the loan principal according to the original July 2019-March 2022 schedule (i.e. without any payment deferrals). The lender and the borrower also agreed to cancel the committed but undisbursed loan balances worth approximately CFA 10 billion (for certain loans with disbursement deadlines that had already passed). Then, in January 2020, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) classified the Government Cameroon as facing a high risk of debt distress. Eighteen months later, during an address before Cameroon’s National Assembly on June 28, 2021, the Minister of Water and Energy (MINEE) Gaston Eloundou Esommba provided an update on the ICBC-financed Bini à Warak Hydroelectric Power Plant Project. He noted that the project had been 'on hold' since November 2019 because ICBC suspended the loan agreement, even though the Government of Cameroon had already mobilized XAF 22 billion of counterpart funding. He also explained that 'the reason for this suspension is that Cameroon did not settle some of its debts towards China on time, so, it is in a cross-default situation.’
justification: Project focuses on trade facilitation and electronic certificate verification, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Trade Facilitation and Electronic Certificate Verification E-Government Project, digital science focus

title: Chinese Government donates table tennis centre in Yaounde Multipurpose Sports Complex
description: On September 24, 2017, Wei Wenhua, the outgoing Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon, promised on behalf of the Chinese Government to provide a modern day table tennis hall at Yaounde Multipurpose Sports Complex.  The official grant agreement was signed and the foundation stone laid on December 27, 2017.  Shanxi Construction and Engineering was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  Work started December 29, 2017 and was expected to be complete by May 2018.  On April 25, 2018, construction was complete, and the hall was officially handed over to the Cameroonian Government, which was represented by Bidoung Nkpatt, the Minister of Sport and Physical Education.  The table tennis court covers 110 square meters and comprises a hall of 300 to 400 seats, two dressing rooms and two offices.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government donates table tennis centre in Yaounde Multipurpose Sports Complex

# Description
On September 24, 2017, Wei Wenhua, the outgoing Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon, promised on behalf of the Chinese Government to provide a modern day table tennis hall at Yaounde Multipurpose Sports Complex.  The official grant agreement was signed and the foundation stone laid on December 27, 2017.  Shanxi Construction and Engineering was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  Work started December 29, 2017 and was expected to be complete by May 2018.  On April 25, 2018, construction was complete, and the hall was officially handed over to the Cameroonian Government, which was represented by Bidoung Nkpatt, the Minister of Sport and Physical Education.  The table tennis court covers 110 square meters and comprises a hall of 300 to 400 seats, two dressing rooms and two offices.
justification: Project is a sports facility donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Table tennis center construction, social infrastructure focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Embassy Provides 10,000,000 Central African Franc Worth of Scholarships to 50 Cameroonian Students (linked to #52457, #52451)
description: On December 13, 2017, the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon awarded 200,000 Central African Franc scholarships to 50 University of Yaounde Il-Soa students, encouraging young learners to invest in education to better serve their nation politically, economically and socially. Each student was given a 200,000 Central African Franc scholarship, leading to a total of amount of 10,000,000 Central African Francs.  The funds were presented to University students by Chinese Ambassador, Wei Wenhua.  This project is linked to project #52457, which describes that this transaction is a result of a commitment between China and Cameroon, in which scholarships worth this amount would be granted every three years beginning in 2016 (see linked ProjectID#52451).  Project #52457 does not have a transaction amount and thus does not risk double-counting Chinese aid.  Interestingly, the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon also provided 50 scholarships of equal value the following year (as captured in this project) to University of Yaounde Il-Soa students.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Description
On December 13, 2017, the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon awarded 200,000 Central African Franc scholarships to 50 University of Yaounde Il-Soa students, encouraging young learners to invest in education to better serve their nation politically, economically and socially. Each student was given a 200,000 Central African Franc scholarship, leading to a total of amount of 10,000,000 Central African Francs.  The funds were presented to University students by Chinese Ambassador, Wei Wenhua.  This project is linked to project #52457, which describes that this transaction is a result of a commitment between China and Cameroon, in which scholarships worth this amount would be granted every three years beginning in 2016 (see linked ProjectID#52451).  Project #52457 does not have a transaction amount and thus does not risk double-counting Chinese aid.  Interestingly, the Chinese Embassy in Cameroon also provided 50 scholarships of equal value the following year (as captured in this project) to University of Yaounde Il-Soa students.
justification: Project focuses on educational scholarships without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarships for university students, education-focused initiative

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Gbaloko Primary School Rehabilitation Project (linked to #56239)
description: In 2017, the Chinese Government provided a grant worth 30 million CFA francs to the Government of the Central African Republic for the Gbaloko Primary School Rehabilitation Project. This project involved the rehabilitation of 6 classrooms, the refurbishment of a school fence, and the provision of 300 new table-benches at Gbaloko Primary School. This school is located in the town of Bégoua, 17 km north of Bangui on the road to Boali at Pk 15.   European Union Military Training Corps and the CAD Defense Forces were responsible for project implementation. The Gbaloko Primary School (also known as Bangui Central Primary School, l’Ecole Gbaloko, Ecole d’Amitié Chine-Centrafrique, and Ecole d'amitié des chinois) was originally constructed with a grant from the Chinese Government (#56239) but it was later vandalized during a period of violence and instability. The school rehabilitation project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on October 8, 2017. The formal handover ceremony was attended by Ma Fullin, Ambassador of the People's Republic of China in the Central African Republic and Michel Loudégué, representing CAR’s Minister of Primary Education.
staff_comments: The French project title is la réhabilitation de l’Ecole Gbaloko.
combined_text:

This school is located in the town of Bégoua, 17 km north of Bangui on the road to Boali at Pk 15.   European Union Military Training Corps and the CAD Defense Forces were responsible for project implementation. The Gbaloko Primary School (also known as Bangui Central Primary School, l’Ecole Gbaloko, Ecole d’Amitié Chine-Centrafrique, and Ecole d'amitié des chinois) was originally constructed with a grant from the Chinese Government (#56239) but it was later vandalized during a period of violence and instability. justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure rehabilitation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Rehabilitation of primary school classrooms, provision of furniture, education sector focus
